Languages

From Peragro Tempus Wiki

While a player's interaction with Peragro Tiempus remains in a single language, the people of Phoria speak a variety of languages and dialects. A character begins play with a default rating in their native language, but no ratings in any other languages.

Spoken languages are generally specializations of the Bard skill, though a few ancient, esoteric, or dead languages are the province of the Sage skill. Attempting to read or write in a languages always defaults to Sage (though it continues to use it's normal specialization ranks) unless the character's ranks in Bard are lower and it is normally checked with that skill.

Each time a character makes a statement into chat the server will perform a skill check (Language used * Sapience), then each recipient will receive a skill check (language used * Sapience). If both individuals pass their check the message is passed on unaltered. Should the sender fail their check by less 50% then the recipient's check is penalized by the amount the sender failed by. If the character's failure is greater than 50% they simply fail to communicate and their entire statement is rendered into gibberish. For each percentage point by which the receiver's check fails 1% (rounding up to the next character) of the sent message is garbled).

While eventually algorithms may be instituted to give the various languages "feels" when garbled, for now the garbled portion is scrambled, randomly increased (varying between reduction to 1 character and an increase of up to twice the original characters), then each character is shifted randomly through the spectrum of possible text characters.

Various dialects exist and will impose a penalty upon the a character trying to use them (either to speak or understand) if they are unfamiliar.

A character can change which language (and dialects) they are speaking in via buttons on the side of the chat window.

Each language is locked, and ranks cannot be gained until at least one rank has been gained through instruction. Gaining experience in a language occurs when the character's roll falls within the range normally needed to do so, but requires that any other participants also succeed at their own roll.
